title: Application of My Webite
text:
Introduction

Hi, I’m Rhyan Goozh.
This presentation focuses on the application of my website: how it represents me not just as a student, but as someone entering the professional world.
I’ve used data science as a tool to express curiosity, personality, and direction.

title: Application of My Webite
text:
Purpose of the Website

Beyond completing assignments, I built this site to:

Showcase my thinking
Highlight my interests
Create a personal, data-driven introduction to who I am

I want the site to feel like a portfolio that reflects more than just skills.

title: Application of My Webite
text:
The Netflix Titles Project

I used string analysis and regular expressions to explore content themes.
Instead of just following the assignment, I asked questions to reflect how I think:
What kinds of stories am I drawn to?
What patterns reflect culture, identity, or emotion?
By following my curiosity through the data, I used the project to express a niche, personal way of engaging with the world.

title: Application of My Webite
text:
Personalizing Data Science

The project helped me realize:

I’m drawn to the stories that come from statistics.
Data can be used creatively—not just to measure, but to reveal how we think.

By building this site, I’m not only learning tools—
I’m showing how I think and what matters to me.

title: Application of My Webite
text:
Application in Adult Life

This site is something I can actually use:

As a talking point in interviews
To demonstrate how I approach complex problems
To highlight curiosity and initiative beyond a resume

It’s a way of presenting myself through work, not just talking about it.
As I move into the next stage of life, I want this site to bring together all parts of me—personal, academic, and professional.

title: Application of My Webite
text:
Final Thoughts

My website is more than a class project—it’s a living example of:

How I connect analytical tools with personal interests
A chance to build something personal beyond just my technical skills
A tool I’ll continue using to reflect who I am and who I’m becoming.

Thanks for listening!

title: FBI Crime Data
text:
In this project, I analyze agency level crime data across all 50 states using the Tidy Tuesday Agencies From the FBI Crime Data API data set. The data set provides detailed information on law enforcement agencies across all 50 states that have submitted data to the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) program and are displayed on the Crime Data Explorer (CDE). This data set is ideal for exploring trends and understanding the fluidity in crime.

# Importing data sets I will analyze 
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-02-18')
agencies <- tuesdata$agencies


# Scatter plot visualization of the distribution of law enforcement agencies by state and agency type 
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)

agencies |>
  count(state, agency_type) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = state, y = n, color = agency_type)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    x = "State",
    y = "Number of Agencies",
    title = "Distribution of Law Enforcement Agencies by State and Type",
    color = "Agency Type"
  ) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "bottom"
    )








Here I created a scatterplot that visualizes the distribution of law enforcement agencies by state and agency type. The x-axis represents the states, while the y-axis displays the number of agencies in each state. Different colors represent different agency types.
This visualization helps identify variations in agency distribution across states and highlights trends in the presence of different law enforcement agency types. It can be useful for understanding the allocation of law enforcement resources and regional differences in agency structures.
Data Source:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2025/2025-02-18/agencies.csv Original FBI data sourced from the FBI Crime Data Explorer API Documentation
Author: TidyTuesday Project
This dataset was sourced from the TidyTuesday project, which provides weekly data challenges for the R community. The underlying data originates from the FBI’s Crime Data Explorer (CDE) API, which includes detailed information on law enforcement agencies across the U.S.:
- The dataset was last committed on February 18, 2025.
- It includes details on agencies that have submitted data to the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program.
- The dataset provides insights into agency types, geographic distribution, and NIBRS participation.

title: Permutation Tests
text:
This analysis investigates whether NHL players are disproportionately born in certain months compared to the general Canadian population. Specifically, we examine if players are more likely to be born in the first quarter of the year (January–March), potentially due to age-based advantages in youth hockey systems.
Our research question is: Are NHL players more likely to be born in the first quarter of the year than we would expect if their birth months followed the same distribution as the general Canadian population?
Hypotheses:

Null hypothesis (H0): The probability that an NHL player is born in the first quarter of the year is equal to the probability that a Canadian is born in the first quarter of the year.
Alternative hypothesis (H1): The probability that an NHL player is born in the first quarter of the year is greater than the probability that a Canadian is born in the first quarter of the year.


library(tidytuesdayR)

# Load the data for January 9, 2024
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-01-09')


library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(purrr)
library(tidyr)
set.seed(123)


# Importing datasets I will analyze 
canada_births_1991_2022 <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/canada_births_1991_2022.csv')
nhl_player_births <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_player_births.csv')
nhl_rosters <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_rosters.csv')
nhl_teams <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_teams.csv')


# Extracting the birth month and filtering relevant data from NHL dataset
nhl_player_births <- nhl_player_births |> 
  mutate(birth_month = month(as.Date(birth_date, format = "%Y-%m-%d"))) |> 
  filter(!is.na(birth_month))

# Preprocessing Canadian data for birth months in the general population and removing NA values
canada_births_1991_2022 <- canada_births_1991_2022 |> 
  filter(!is.na(month))


# Summary Statistics
# Plot visualization of the distributions of birth months for NHL players and the Canadian population

# Plot for NHL players
ggplot(nhl_player_births, aes(x = birth_month)) +  # Use 'birth_month' from nhl_player_births
  geom_bar(fill = "skyblue", color = "black") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12, labels = month.abb) +
  labs(title = "Birth Month Distribution of NHL Players", x = "Month", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()







# Plot for Canadian population
ggplot(canada_births_1991_2022, aes(x = month)) +  # Use 'month' from canada_births_1991_2022
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12, labels = month.abb) +
  labs(title = "Birth Month Distribution of Canadian Population", x = "Month", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()









# Summary Statistics
# Calculating the proportion of players and population born in the first quarter (Jan-Mar)

# NHL first quarter proportion
nhl_first_quarter <- nhl_player_births |> 
  filter(birth_month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |> 
  summarize(first_quarter_prop = n() / nrow(nhl_player_births))

# Canadian first quarter proportion
canadian_first_quarter <- canada_births_1991_2022 |> 
  filter(month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |>  # 'month' column in the Canada dataset
  summarize(first_quarter_prop = n() / nrow(canada_births_1991_2022))

# View results
nhl_first_quarter

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  first_quarter_prop
               <dbl>
1              0.298

canadian_first_quarter

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  first_quarter_prop
               <dbl>
1               0.25



perm_test <- function(nhl_data, canadian_data, n_perm = 5000) {
  # Combine both datasets into one
  all_months <- c(nhl_data$birth_month, canadian_data$month)
  group_labels <- c(rep("NHL", nrow(nhl_data)), rep("Canada", nrow(canadian_data)))
  
  # Observed difference
  observed_diff <- mean(nhl_data$birth_month %in% 1:3) - mean(canadian_data$month %in% 1:3)
  
  # Permutation distribution
  perm_diffs <- replicate(n_perm, {
    shuffled_labels <- sample(group_labels)
    q1_prop_nhl <- mean(all_months[shuffled_labels == "NHL"] %in% 1:3)
    q1_prop_canada <- mean(all_months[shuffled_labels == "Canada"] %in% 1:3)
    q1_prop_nhl - q1_prop_canada
  })
  
  tibble(observed = observed_diff, permuted = perm_diffs)
}

We conduct a right-tailed permutation test to evaluate whether a higher proportion of NHL players are born in the first quarter of the year (January–March) compared to the general Canadian population. If the resulting p-value is below the significance level (0.05), we reject the null hypothesis that birth month distributions are the same. Otherwise, we fail to reject it.

# Run the permutation test
perm_results <- perm_test(nhl_player_births, canada_births_1991_2022)

# Extract observed and permuted differences
observed_diff <- perm_results$observed[1]
permuted_diffs <- perm_results$permuted

# Calculate p-value
p_value <- mean(permuted_diffs >= observed_diff)
p_value

[1] 0.0232


The permutation test shows that the proportion of NHL players born in Q1 (January–March) is significantly higher than expected compared to the Canadian population. With a p-value of 0.0208, we reject the null hypothesis that the birth month distributions are the same, suggesting a real bias in birth month representation among NHL players.
Conclusion:
The permutation test indicates that the proportion of NHL players born in the first quarter of the year (January–March) is significantly higher than what we would expect based on the distribution of birth months in the general Canadian population. With a p-value of 0.0208, we reject the null hypothesis that the birth month distributions are the same. This suggests a real bias in birth month representation among NHL players, where they are more likely to be born in the first quarter of the year.
While this finding aligns with the concept of the relative age effect (RAE)—where players born earlier in the year may have a competitive advantage—it’s important to recognize that other factors such as sample size, dataset variations, or specific characteristics of the NHL player pool could influence these results. Further research might consider these factors to deepen our understanding of birth month biases in hockey and other sports.
Data Source:
This analysis uses data from the TidyTuesday project for the week of January 9, 2024, accessed via the tidytuesdayR package and the TidyTuesday GitHub repository: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/main/data/2024/2024-01-09
Direct provenance for each dataset:
Canadian Births (1991-2022): This dataset includes monthly birth counts for Canadian residents from 1991 to 2022. It is available at: https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1710000901
NHL Player Births, NHL Rosters, NHL Teams: This dataset contains birthdates of NHL players. The original data can be accessed through the NHL API: https://www.nhl.com/stats/
All datasets are publicly available via GitHub and were accessed using the tidytuesdayR package.

title: Text Analysis
text:
In this project, I analyzed the Netflix Movies and TV Shows dataset to explore trends and insights into potential Netflix consumer engagement strategy. This dataset, sourced from Kaggle and made available through TidyTuesday, provides information on titles, genres, release years, duration, and descriptions.

# Importing datasets I will analyze 
netflix_titles <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-04-20/netflix_titles.csv')


library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)
library(stringr)
library(plotly)
library(dplyr)


Question 1: What are the most commonly produced genres on Netflix?

# Convert listed genres to lowercase
netflix_titles <- netflix_titles |> 
  mutate(listed_in = str_to_lower(listed_in))


# Split genres into individual rows
genre_trends <- netflix_titles |> 
  separate_rows(listed_in, sep = ", ") |> 
  count(listed_in, sort = TRUE) |> 
  rename(primary_genre = listed_in, total_count = n)


# Keep only the top 10 genres
top_10_genres <- genre_trends |> 
  slice_max(total_count, n = 10)


# Bar plot with genre names on x-axis
genre_plot <- ggplot(top_10_genres, aes(x = reorder(primary_genre, total_count), y = total_count)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Most Commonly Produced Genres on Netflix",
    x = "Genre",
    y = "Count"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

print(genre_plot)








This first bar chart displays the top 10 most frequently produced genres in the Netflix dataset, with Drama, Comedy, and International Movies and TV Shows appearing most often. These counts highlight which genres are most commonly represented in the catalog. While Drama and Comedy have a strong presence—potentially reflecting a general demand for emotionally engaging or lighthearted content—it’s important to note that these patterns don’t necessarily reflect Netflix’s production priorities or viewer preferences. They may instead reflect what content happened to be available or licensed during specific periods. The chart simply shows which genres appear most frequently, offering a snapshot of how the catalog is distributed across different types of content. Providing this visual overview helps contextualize genre diversity without assuming intent behind the distribution.


Question 2: Is there a relationship between movie length and release year?

# # Filter to include only movies by removing rows where the duration field contains "season" (TV shows)
netflix_titles <- netflix_titles |> 
  mutate(
# Extract duration for movies by using a regular expression to exclude TV shows.The pattern uses a negative lookahead to ignore any "duration" values containing "season"
    movie_length = as.numeric(str_extract(duration, "^(?!.*seasons).*\\d+"))
  )

# Filter to only movies and ensure there are valid movie lengths and release years
movie_data <- netflix_titles |> 
  filter(
    type == "Movie" & 
    !is.na(movie_length) & 
    !is.na(release_year) &
    movie_length > 0
  )

# Check the first few rows of filtered movie data
head(movie_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 13
  show_id type  title director      cast  country date_added release_year rating
  <chr>   <chr> <chr> <chr>         <chr> <chr>   <chr>             <dbl> <chr> 
1 s2      Movie 7:19  Jorge Michel… Demi… Mexico  December …         2016 TV-MA 
2 s3      Movie 23:59 Gilbert Chan  Tedd… Singap… December …         2011 R     
3 s4      Movie 9     Shane Acker   Elij… United… November …         2009 PG-13 
4 s5      Movie 21    Robert Luket… Jim … United… January 1…         2008 PG-13 
5 s7      Movie 122   Yasir Al Yas… Amin… Egypt   June 1, 2…         2019 TV-MA 
6 s8      Movie 187   Kevin Reynol… Samu… United… November …         1997 R     
# ℹ 4 more variables: duration <chr>, listed_in <chr>, description <chr>,
#   movie_length <dbl>

# Scatter plot of movie length vs. release year with trend line
length_vs_year_plot <- ggplot(movie_data, aes(x = release_year, y = movie_length)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "darkred") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Movie Length and Release Year",
    x = "Release Year",
    y = "Movie Length (minutes)"
  )
print(length_vs_year_plot)








In this second plot, to ensure accurate analysis of movie length, I filtered out entries where the duration field included the word “season,” which typically indicates a TV series rather than a standalone film. This step, implemented using a negative lookahead (^(?!.seasons).\d+), allowed me to isolate only actual movie runtimes (e.g., “90 minutes”) for a more reliable analysis. The scatter plot reveals a slight decreasing trend in movie lengths from 1940 to 2020. While we can’t infer Netflix’s intentions or content strategy from this pattern alone—since changes could reflect shifts in genre popularity or catalog composition—it does suggest a general trend toward shorter films in the dataset. To reduce the noise from individual data points, the second plot groups movie lengths by decade. This broader view helps make changes in average run times more visible and illustrates how the types of movies available have varied over time. Including this narrative perspective helps contextualize the observed patterns without assuming intent behind them.


How many titles on Netflix use “The” in it?

the_count <- sum(str_detect(netflix_titles[["title"]], "\\bthe\\b"))
the_count

[1] 558


I used a regular expression to count how many titles on Netflix contain the word “the,” using the pattern \bthe\b. This method identified 558 titles with the word “the” in their title. This count reflects the prevalence of titles that include this common article, but it does not suggest any intentional pattern or strategy behind Netflix’s content naming choices.


Count how many titles contain a four-digit year

year_count <- sum(str_detect(netflix_titles$title, "\\b\\d{4}\\b"))
year_count

[1] 42


I used an additional regular expression to count how many titles contain a four-digit year (e.g., “1994” or “2020”), using the pattern \b\d{4}\b. This helps identify how often titles reference specific years, which could suggest biographical, historical, or period-themed content. The output was 42 titles, indicating that such date references are relatively uncommon in the dataset.
Analysis on Tables/Plots:
This dataset offers valuable insights into trends within Netflix’s catalog, highlighting patterns in genre frequency and movie lengths over time. While these findings do not reveal Netflix’s internal strategy or intent, they do show which genres appear most often and how movie runtimes have varied across different decades. The analysis focuses on the most commonly produced genres and the relationship between movie lengths and release years, offering a clearer picture of how the content in this dataset is distributed and how it has changed over time.
Data Source: Netflix Movies and TV Shows Dataset https://www.kaggle.com/shivamb/netflix-shows?select=netflix_titles.csv
Author: Shivam Bansal
This dataset, sourced from Kaggle, originates from Flixable, a third-party Netflix search engine. It contains information about movies and TV shows available on Netflix since 2019, including:

Attributes such as title, genre, language, release year, and rating.
Insights into patterns related to content production, genre trends, and the evolution of media consumption.
Integration with external data sets like IMDB and Rotten Tomatoes for deeper analysis.
The data was last updated on Kaggle by Shivam Bansal.

title: Ethics: Data and Power
text:
TikTok’s popularity is driven in part by its ability to show users hyper-personalized content and advertisements through machine learning algorithms. These algorithms analyze behavioral data such as watch time, likes, replays, and comments to create a “For You” feed and deliver targeted ads. Behind the scenes, this involves extensive user profiling, predictive modeling, and the inference of demographic characteristics such as gender and age. While TikTok does not always collect demographic data directly, public documentation like the 2021 Privacy Policy suggests that behavioral signals are used to estimate user traits—though the specific methods are not fully disclosed.
This process raises several ethical concerns. How much do users actually consent to? Is the data really anonymous? Can inferred attributes lead to discrimination? This project explores four key ethical dilemmas embedded in TikTok’s data practices.


One of the central issues is whether users have meaningfully consented to TikTok’s data collection and use. As Barocas & Nissenbaum (2009) explain, the typical “notice and consent” model fails to provide genuine understanding of how data will be used—especially when future uses are unclear or hidden behind complex policy language. TikTok’s 2021 Privacy Policy describes the collection of behavioral data for purposes like improving services and targeting ads. However, it does not clearly outline the full extent of personalization or profiling algorithms used to infer user characteristics, nor the third parties involved in data sharing (TikTok, 2021). Given the opacity of these systems and how often users accept terms without reading them, true informed consent is likely not possible. Furthermore, as Barocas & Nissenbaum also point out, app design often includes dark patterns—subtle design tricks that nudge users to accept permissions without realizing their implications. This raises the question: can users really opt out of a system that is designed to obscure their choices?
It is also worth considering that TikTok likely views “improving services” as a broad umbrella under which profiling algorithms are deployed. This raises an ethical issue not only of transparency but also of whether users even have a clear understanding of the actual consequences of consenting to such data collection, particularly when the systems are so complex and opaque. It is possible that the “improving services” language conceals the more intrusive aspects of TikTok’s data practices, such as the detailed profiling algorithms it uses for ad targeting.



TikTok claims that some of its data is anonymized or aggregated, but this doesn’t guarantee privacy. According to Leetaru (2016), even supposedly anonymous data can often be re-identified when combined with other data sources, a process known as “mosaicking.” For example, details like location, usage patterns, and device metadata can often be linked back to individuals, especially when tied to inferred demographic profiles. If TikTok uses behavioral cues to infer traits like age or gender and combines them with device identifiers or app usage metadata, the risk of re-identification becomes real. This is especially troubling for users who believe their data is anonymous when, in fact, it may still expose them to targeting or profiling.
This risk becomes even more critical if TikTok shares this data with third parties or if there is a data breach. However, if the data were only used in-house, the likelihood of this re-identification risk might be reduced, though it would still depend on the robustness of TikTok’s internal privacy protections and the degree to which the data is effectively anonymized. Even without data being shared externally, the company’s ability to re-identify users based on aggregated data highlights significant privacy concerns, especially as this anonymized data may still be leveraged for highly specific ad targeting.



TikTok’s algorithms may also use behavioral data in ways that were not explicitly stated in its policies, leading to unintended consequences. For example, content engagement patterns can be used to infer when users are feeling vulnerable or emotionally unstable—data that advertisers or recommendation engines could exploit. This creates ethical concerns, especially for younger users or those struggling with mental health. As Barocas & Nissenbaum (2009) warn, data collected for one purpose may be repurposed for another, potentially harming users who were unaware of such risks. When TikTok’s algorithm detects that a user is binge-watching certain types of content (e.g., related to body image or depression), it may double down and promote similar content, potentially reinforcing harmful behavior. This scenario reflects how data can be used in unintended, damaging ways that affect both individuals and communities.
If TikTok’s data is used only in-house, it might mitigate some of the risks of exploitation, but it does not fully address the ethical concern that the data might still lead to harm by inadvertently reinforcing negative behaviors. The algorithms themselves, especially in their reliance on user behavior, can cause undue influence by continually promoting content that could further exploit or exacerbate the emotional states of users. The unintended consequences of such a feedback loop could perpetuate harmful patterns, particularly if vulnerable users are continuously exposed to content that reinforces negative body image, mental health struggles, or other damaging behaviors.



TikTok does not ask users for race or gender directly, but it still infers these attributes using behavioral patterns, language, and possibly facial features from videos—though TikTok has not publicly confirmed all technical details. This practice aligns with Buolamwini & Gebru’s (2018) work on algorithmic bias, which shows how demographic inferences can lead to discriminatory outcomes—especially when training data is not representative or when inferred demographics become proxies for exclusion. If TikTok’s ad system uses inferred gender or race to determine who sees certain ads or content, this could result in proxy discrimination. For example, an advertiser may unintentionally exclude users that the algorithm identifies as “less profitable” based on biased inferences. The ethical dilemma here is not just whether race or gender should be used—but whether the algorithm is replicating or reinforcing social inequalities through proxies it was never explicitly told to use.
Even if TikTok does not directly collect demographic information, the algorithms’ ability to infer characteristics like gender and race may still create opportunities for proxy discrimination that disproportionately affects marginalized groups. If the algorithms reinforce biases or make assumptions based on incomplete data, it could lead to biased ad targeting, limiting users’ access to certain products or services based on demographic assumptions that might not even be accurate. This further complicates the ethical landscape, as the platform’s data-driven decisions could inadvertently perpetuate inequality in ways that are difficult for users to challenge or even recognize.

These algorithms analyze behavioral data such as watch time, likes, replays, and comments to create a “For You” feed and deliver targeted ads. This process raises several ethical concerns. How much do users actually consent to? Is the data really anonymous? Can inferred attributes lead to discrimination? This project explores four key ethical dilemmas embedded in TikTok’s data practices.

If TikTok’s ad system uses inferred gender or race to determine who sees certain ads or content, this could result in proxy discrimination. For example, an advertiser may unintentionally exclude users that the algorithm identifies as “less profitable” based on biased inferences. The ethical dilemma here is not just whether race or gender should be used—but whether the algorithm is replicating or reinforcing social inequalities through proxies it was never explicitly told to use.
Even if TikTok does not directly collect demographic information, the algorithms’ ability to infer characteristics like gender and race may still create opportunities for proxy discrimination that disproportionately affects marginalized groups. If the algorithms reinforce biases or make assumptions based on incomplete data, it could lead to biased ad targeting, limiting users’ access to certain products or services based on demographic assumptions that might not even be accurate. This further complicates the ethical landscape, as the platform’s data-driven decisions could inadvertently perpetuate inequality in ways that are difficult for users to challenge or even recognize.

title: Ethics: Data and Power
text:
References

Barocas, S., & Nissenbaum, H. (2009). On Notice: The Trouble with Notice and Consent. In Proceedings of the Engaging Data Forum: The First International Forum on the Application and Management of Personal Electronic Information.
Buolamwini, J., & Gebru, T. (2018). Gender Shades: Intersectional Accuracy Disparities in Commercial Gender Classification. Proceedings of Machine Learning Research: 81, 77–91.
Leetaru, K. (2016). The Big Data Era of Mosaicked Deidentification: Can We Anonymize Data Anymore? Forbes. https://www.forbes.com/sites/kalevleetaru/2016/09/26/the-big-data-era-of-mosaicked-deidentification-can-we-anonymize-data-anymore/
TikTok. (2021). Privacy Policy. https://www.tiktok.com/legal/privacy-policy

title: SQL Analysis
text:
This project explores how traffic stop outcomes vary by race and gender across California, Texas, and North Carolina. Using the Stanford Open Policing Project SQL database, we query traffic stop data from California, Texas, and North Carolina to identify potential disparities in stop outcomes such as arrests, searches, or warnings. Our analysis includes grouped summaries and visualizations to highlight trends and differences across the states.


Code
# Connecting to the Traffic Database
library(RMariaDB)

con_traffic <- DBI::dbConnect(
 RMariaDB::MariaDB(),
 dbname = "traffic",
 host = Sys.getenv("TRAFFIC_HOST"),
 user = Sys.getenv("TRAFFIC_USER"),
 password = Sys.getenv("TRAFFIC_PWD")
)

title: SQL Analysis
text:
Checking for Missing Values


Code
-- Check missing subject_race in CA
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ca_statewide_2023_01_26 WHERE subject_race IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




1







Code
-- Check missing subject_sex in CA
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ca_statewide_2023_01_26 WHERE subject_sex IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




96







Code
-- Check missing outcome in CA
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ca_statewide_2023_01_26 WHERE outcome IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




9588775





California Missing Values: There is 1 missing value for subject_race, suggesting almost complete data in this category. The subject_sex field has 96 missing values, which is still minimal relative to the dataset size. However, the outcome variable is missing in 9,588,775 records, indicating a severe gap in outcome reporting that could significantly limit analysis and raise questions about data collection methods or system design.


Code
-- Check missing subject_race in TX
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM tx_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE subject_race IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




352







Code
-- Check missing subject_sex in TX
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM tx_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE subject_sex IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




436







Code
-- Check missing outcome in TX
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM tx_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE outcome IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




2357





Texas Missing Values: The dataset shows 352 missing values for subject_race and 436 missing values for subject_sex, which are relatively small proportions and suggest generally good data quality for these variables. There are 2,357 missing values for outcome, a non-negligible amount that should be noted in any evaluation of the dataset’s completeness.


Code
-- Check missing subject_race in NC
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM nc_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE subject_race IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




18







Code
-- Check missing subject_sex in NC
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM nc_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE subject_sex IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




18







Code
-- Check missing outcome in NC
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM nc_statewide_2020_04_01 WHERE outcome IS NULL;



1 records


COUNT(*)




605059





North Carolina Missing Values: Both subject_race and subject_sex have 18 missing values each, reflecting strong consistency in demographic reporting. On the other hand, 605,059 records are missing outcome values, which could meaningfully affect any modeling or statistical inference relying on outcomes and highlights the importance of addressing or accounting for this missingness.

title: SQL Analysis
text: SQL Table Queries

title: SQL Analysis
section: Load Data into R from SQL Queries
text:
Load Data into R from SQL Queries


Code
# Query CA results
ca_data <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con_traffic, "
  SELECT 
    'CA' AS state,
    subject_race,
    subject_sex,
    outcome,
    COUNT(*) AS count
  FROM ca_statewide_2023_01_26
  WHERE subject_race IS NOT NULL 
    AND subject_sex IS NOT NULL 
    AND outcome IS NOT NULL
  GROUP BY subject_race, subject_sex, outcome
  ORDER BY count DESC
")

# Query TX results
tx_data <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con_traffic, "
  SELECT 
    'TX' AS state,
    subject_race,
    subject_sex,
    outcome,
    COUNT(*) AS count
  FROM tx_statewide_2020_04_01
  WHERE subject_race IS NOT NULL 
    AND subject_sex IS NOT NULL 
    AND outcome IS NOT NULL
  GROUP BY subject_race, subject_sex, outcome
  ORDER BY count DESC
")

# Query NC results
nc_data <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con_traffic, "
  SELECT 
    'NC' AS state,
    subject_race,
    subject_sex,
    outcome,
    COUNT(*) AS count
  FROM nc_statewide_2020_04_01
  WHERE subject_race IS NOT NULL 
    AND subject_sex IS NOT NULL 
    AND outcome IS NOT NULL
  GROUP BY subject_race, subject_sex, outcome
  ORDER BY count DESC
")

title: SQL Analysis
text:
Combine States Data


Code
# Combine the data from CA, TX, and NC
combined_data <- rbind(ca_data, tx_data, nc_data)

# Convert 'state' to a factor for easier plotting
combined_data$state <- factor(combined_data$state, levels = c('CA', 'TX', 'NC'))

# Convert 'subject_sex' and 'subject_race' to factors
combined_data$subject_sex <- factor(combined_data$subject_sex)
combined_data$subject_race <- factor(combined_data$subject_race)

title: SQL Analysis
text:
Two Well Labled Plots


Code
# First Plot: Traffic stop outcomes by race across the states
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)

all_data <- bind_rows(ca_data, tx_data, nc_data)

race_summary <- all_data |>
  group_by(state, subject_race) |>
  summarise(total_stops = sum(count), .groups = 'drop')

ggplot(race_summary, aes(x = subject_race, y = total_stops, fill = state)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +  # Added this to format the y-axis
  labs(
    title = "Traffic Stop Outcomes by Race Across States",
    x = "Race",
    y = "Number of Traffic Stops",
    fill = "State",
    caption = "Data from the Stanford Open Policing Project"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))









The bar chart compares the number of traffic stops by race across California, North Carolina, and Texas. Across all three states, White drivers experienced the highest number of stops, followed by Hispanic and Black drivers. There is a significant drop-off in the number of stops for drivers categorized as Asian/Pacific Islander, “Other,” and “Unknown,” indicating that stops are heavily concentrated among a few racial groups. Texas is leading in the number of stops for White, Hispanic, and Unknown drivers. North Carolina shows a particularly high number of stops for Black drivers compared to California and Texas.


Code
# Second Plot: Traffic stop outcomes by gender across the states
library(scales)

gender_summary <- all_data |>
  group_by(state, subject_sex) |>
  summarise(total_stops = sum(count), .groups = 'drop')

ggplot(gender_summary, aes(x = subject_sex, y = total_stops, fill = state)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +  # Added this to format the y-axis
  labs(
    title = "Traffic Stop Outcomes by Gender Across States",
    x = "Gender",
    y = "Number of Traffic Stops",
    fill = "State",
    caption = "Data from the Stanford Open Policing Project"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









This plot shows traffic stop outcomes by gender across California, North Carolina, and Texas. Male drivers account for a noticeably higher number of stops in each state compared to female drivers. The gap between male and female stops is consistent, but Texas records a particularly large number of male stops relative to the other two states. California has about 5 million more male stops than North Caroline but the number of stop for women between the two states is relatively the same. Overall, gender appears to be a significant factor in the frequency of traffic stops.

title: SQL Analysis
text:
Insights
This analysis shows how the frequency and type of traffic stop outcomes (e.g., warnings, arrests, searches) vary by race, gender, and state. Across California, Texas, and North Carolina, white male drivers are stopped most often, but Black and Hispanic individuals—especially males—face higher rates of searches and arrests, particularly in Texas and North Carolina. White drivers, especially females, are more likely to receive warnings. These trends point to consistent disparities and potential bias in traffic enforcement across state lines.

title: SQL Analysis
text:
Reference
Pierson, Emma, Camelia Simoiu, Jan Overgoor, Sam Corbett-Davies, Daniel Jenson, Amy Shoemaker, Vignesh Ramachandran, et al. 2020. “A Large-Scale Analysis of Racial Disparities in Police Stops Across the United States.” Nature Human Behaviour, 1–10.


Code
DBI::dbDisconnect(con_traffic)

title: About Me
text:
Rhyan Goozh


Welcome to my website! I am a student at Pomona College (’27) majoring in Economics and minoring in Data Science. At Pomona I am an Associate Consultant for Pomona Consulting Group and the Finance Director for Party With a Purpose Dance Marathon Club. I also play on the Pomona Woman’s Varsity Lacrosse team. This summer (2025), I will be interning as a Finance Associate at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC).

title: Data Viz
text:
About this site

2+4

[1] 6

title: Valentines Day Consumer Data
text:
In this project, I analyze consumer spending on Valentines Day using the Tidy Tuesday Valentine’s Day survey data from the National Retail Federation (NRF) Valentine’s Day Data Center. The data set provides detailed information on how consumers celebrate Valentine’s Day annually for over a decade (2010 - 2022) and uses interactive charts to explore a demographic break down on both spending and gift type. This data set is ideal for exploring and understanding relationships in consumer spending.

# Importing data sets I will analyze 
gifts_age <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-02-13/gifts_age.csv')


# Scatter plot visualization of money spent on Valentines Day across different age groups  
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)

ggplot(gifts_age, aes(x = Age, y = SpendingCelebrating, group = 1)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3) +  
  geom_line(color = "red", linewidth = 1) + 
  labs(
    title = "Percentage of People Spending Money on Valentine's Day by Age",
    x = "Age Group",
    y = "Percentage Spending (%)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








Here I created a scatterplot to visualizes the percentage of people spending money on Valentine’s Day across different age groups. The x-axis represents various age groups, while the y-axis indicates the percentage of individuals in each group who report spending money on the holiday. A red line is used to connect the points, highlighting the trend in spending participation across age demographics.
This visualization helps identify spending habits among different generations, showing whether younger or older individuals are more likely to participate financially in Valentine’s Day celebrations.
Data Source:
https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/infinator/happy-valentines-day-2022
Author: National Retail Federation (NRF)
This data was sourced from the TidyTuesday project, which provides weekly data challenges for the R community. Specifically, the dataset focuses on consumer spending on valentine’s Day:
- The dataset originates from the National Retail Federation’s annual Valentine’s Day surveys and last updated November 2024.
- Data spans from 2010 to 2022 and examines spending habits by age group.
- This dataset provides insights into planned spending on different types of gifts and overall spending participation.
